Collapsing, widespread
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Widespread collapsing where the facets at the ground exist. Moving to SE aspects the existence of facets that were collapsing was more varied. Closer to 10k and ESE the facets were easy to find and were collapsing with greater frequency.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on different slopes
Collapsing, widespread
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: From 8k and up we experienced many collapses of varying sizes. The snowpack varied very little on E and SE aspects. The main difference was the existence of facets at the ground.
11/23 BSH down 70CM's

User.name: Brandon Schwartz

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, localized
Collapsing, localized
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Karen Bockel's pit data. About 250' down the NE Ridge and dropping off to the north side. Snow depth was highly variable on the ridge and in the lee - varying between 30cm and 150cm. Upper elevation pits had a thin ice lens that was likely capping the October Snow. This pit had the largest facets that I have seen in the Teton Pass Area this season. One localized collapse as we reascended to the summit of Glory.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized
Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Several skier triggered slides south of Teton Pass on 11/24. Wolf Trap slide in Avalanchee Bowl was a SS-ASr-R2-D2-O down 50cm on the lower layer of buried surface hoar, but above the November Facet Layer (NFL). Crown profile ECT's did not propagate ~24 hours after the avalanche. Christmas Tree slide initiated in SH and stepped down into facets.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: ECTP 11 @40cm Sudden Planar CT 1 @75cm Sudden Planar When clearing new snow at the start of compression test the whole block fell into the pit.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; We skied slope
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Stability tests showed poor structure, low propagation propensity and low strength. New snow was not cohesive enough to form a slab, but with settlement could become more dangerous sitting on top of FCsf at 35-37cm. When skiing today, snow was so light we were mostly skiing on bed surface/old ski tracks with 30+cm on top

No slab but poor structure

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Slope skied well. New wind slab layer was building throughout the day, with high wind gust. Pit confirmed what CAIC report. BTL snow was much more wet, and TL to ATL it was much more dry.

Today it started snowing at 7 am. Where we dug the snowpack was shallow with layers of facets and crusts, but no slab. We saw a typical early-season, faceted snowpack on an upper elevation, north facing slope.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on different slopes; Poor pit location
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: snow blowing over the ridge with clouds rolling over and down into the east side of the range, stability tests were unreliable with pockets of 3mm graupel spread throughout test pit, skewing results. Saw one small natural avalanche in a windloaded gully, maybe 5-7m wide and 15-20cm deep

October rain crust down 50 cms is slowly breaking down, but still supportable. 4F slab down 15 cms also provide good support for travel on skis. We got two different ECT results, one failing on a layer of facets below rain crust, another failing on faceted layer above the crust. Both were full propagation.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: October Crust Layer (OCL) about 5cm thick, deteriorating into facets, losing strength. Could be problematic with future loads. Total snow depth in adjacent path start zones estimated to be 120 to 180cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug near large crack in a large dune of winddrifted snow. Little snow in the alpine, all blown into leeward slopes.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes
We skied slope
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 10cm of new snow over a light wind crust over the 40cm of new snow that fell on the 6/8/18. size 1 to 2 natural avalanches had run during the storm and had released on steep, high SE aspects. A larger, 2.5, but isolated, steep, south aspect, natural avalanche had released from beneath an ice fall. The failure layer appeared to be the new/old bond from the 6/8/18 storm which then stepped down to basal blue ice. However the new snow seems to be bonding with time and stability was good generally, although caution is needed on steep, shady unsupported slopes.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Periodic dry snow avalanche activity over the winter likely contributes to this observation's overall depth and consistency, located in transition/runout zone from slope above. Warm and wet weather pattern: daily rain showers with no freeze recorded at Lower Titus (9156') in past 7 days. Recent WS D2 activity noted 0.5km SW, originating from cornice drops at 10,000' ridgeline NE aspect. LyteProbe data collection mission.

ALP, läsluttning, stenig/mossig mark.

Quick survey of N vs S facing aspects. Backed off from a nearby 39* SE aspect with HS less than 60cm of F- slush. This N aspect was within 200' of week-old wet slab (though not a crown profile per se), and appeared stronger than expected.
Uppvärmd sluttning, ALP.
Läsida med uppvärmd snö i ytan, ALP.
ALP. Läsluttning, stenig mark ev mossa/gräs. Samma asp/elev som SZ ovan klipporna.
Läsida som fått drevsnö, ALP.
Läsida, ALP.
